title: Which country will win the most gold medals at the 2018 Winter Olympic Games?
preds: How they made the question close AFTER the Closing Ceremony was weird.  I clicked through on the newsletter saying it had over 240-odd forecasts, so thought I'd see how badly I scored since I had it 100% Germany LOL. Changed it to the correct answer so my score won't suck as bad. Edit: Had it at 100% for Norway on AC https://alphacast.cultivateforecasts.com/questions/3922-winter-olympics-2018-which-country-will-win-the-most-number-of-gold-medals
I thought norway had the edge in this. I should have read the question information for in the event of a tie - norway was always so far ahead in total medal count and that crazy conversion rate!
Norway owns the Winter. Their lifestyle matches many of these games.
No other country can get more medals now
This was a mess, used wrong data, from the info I found, didn't seem like Norway had any more gold medal events left. Confusing!
Canceling insurance policy against a German win.

Norway has won more medals than any country in the Winter Olympics. If it and Germany are tied for the number of gold medals, it will boil down to the total number of medals each country has, and Norway has the upper advantage. While most of the games have concluded, with Norway and Germany tied for the number of gold medals, the rest of the games will have little impact because these games are not the traditional strengths of Norway and Germany and will count a different country as the medalist.
After the nail biting hockey match, the result now depends entirely on the mass start.

Germany got the gold in the bobsled, as expected, and ALMOST got the gold in ice hockey!  Making Germany up by 1.  Now, it's up to Marit to get a gold for Norway in the women's 30km classic nordic ski to tie the medal count at 14-14.

Germany 14, Norway 13.  Close, but no cigar for Germany in the Ice Hockey. Bjoergen (Norway) with a 50 second lead at the half-way mark of the 30km Cross Country Skiing, and seems to be increasing her lead. What a tight finish for this question!!!
I believe it to be accurate.

The question for this week is “Which country will win the most gold medals at the 2018 Winter Olympic Games?”  I have chosen to assign these probability percentages to the following countries: Germany (90%), Norway (10%), and 0% for the United States (9 gold medals), Canada (11 gold medals), Netherlands (8 gold medals), and the last option in the question, “another country.” (No other country than the previously mentioned countries won more than 8 medals.)  Currently as I write this forecast, Norway has 13 gold medals and Germany just won their 14th gold medal in the 4 men bobsledding competition and are in the middle of the first period of the gold medal hockey game against the Olympic Athletes from Russia.  Although the OAR hockey team has better young and veteran players, as well as a historically superior hockey tradition to that of the Germans, it is not a foregone conclusion.  Germany has advanced as a severe underdog in this tournament, recently beating the highly-favored Canadians in the semifinal game.  After the hockey game, the only event in the Olympics is the women’s 30-kilometer cross country skiing competition.  The Norwegians are highly favored to win the gold, as their 3 competing skiers are in the top 5 in the world in this event; however, this event is historically random as earlier today, the men’s 50-kilometer cross country skiing competition was not won by a top 5 ranked skier.  I am assigning a 90% valuation to Germany winning the most gold medals, but a 10% chance remains with the Norwegians.  If the Germans lose the hockey final and one of the Norwegian skiers wins the final cross-country race of the Olympics, both countries will have 14 gold medals.  If this occurs, the Good Judgment Project “will use the total number of medals to serve as a tiebreaker, followed by the total silver medals and then bronze medals, if needed.”  Currently, Germany has 30 medals and Norway has 38 medals.  Germany will not be able to catch up with Norway, even though they are guaranteed a silver if they lose the hockey final, but this will only give them a total of 31 medals.  At the same time, Norway can win 3 more medals if they sweep the women’s cross-country skiing competition, which would give them a grand total of 41 medals in the Olympics, which is highly unlikely and improbable.  In the end, Germany has the best realistic chance to get the most gold medals, as they are in a tight game against the Olympic Athletes from Russia team and there are way too many variables in the cross-country competition, such as weather, crashes, equipment malfunction, and a 47-woman starting field, for Norway to get the 14th gold medal.  Ultimately, Germany will get the most gold medals, but a 10% doubt remains as Norway has won the most total medals by any country in a single Olympics, thus they cannot be discounted, especially in their strongest and most popular sport.
Updating after bobsleigh using numbers computed here (5am is not a time for doing math) : http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/699593

Backed it off some from an earlier answer using @AliM forecast probabilities and adding in the fact that Germany won bobsled. Was a little surprised that the win didnt change the percentage by too much.

Looks like Germany has the lead with 14 gold medals (Bobsled team just got a gold medal). Looking for info on what other competitions are left to see if there are any other chances for Norway to score.
Germany  Bobsleigh lead after 3rd run looks strong. Hedging forecast.
Reviewed a few people's reasoning for their selections and increased Germany by 2 and decreased Norway by 2.  Still pretty close.

I've taken a leaf out of @Ken_Barns book (http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/699018) but reduced the probability of Germany winning the bobsleigh to 0.8. When I ran the numbers (see below) I got a 0.49 for Germany and 0.51 for Norway. As Ken said : too close too call. @Anneinak  Events :
- B : Germany wins bobsleigh
- H : Germany wins Ice Hockey
- S : Norway wins skiing P(B) = 0.8
P(H) = 0.3
P(S) = 0.6 B H S
1 1 1 p 0.8x0.3x0.6 0.144 G
1 1 0 p 0.8x0.3x0.4 0.096 G
1 0 1 p 0.8x0.7x0.6 0.336 N
0 1 1 p 0.2x0.3x0.6 0.036 N
0 0 1 p 0.2x0.7x0.6 0.084 N
0 1 0 p 0.2x0.3x0.4 0.024 G
1 0 0 p 0.8x0.7x0.4 0.224 G
0 0 0 p 0.2x0.7x0.4 0.056 N G 0.144 + 0.096 +0.024+0.224 0.49
N 0.336+0.036+0.084+0.056 0.51

A wise forecaster recently commented that when he found himself worried about a forecast, he took it as an indication that he had forecast his hopes/fears rather than the facts. I've been worried about this forecast!  I am such a slow learner!  Every time I've forecast on sporting events I've made the same mistake; I've made too extreme of a forecast.  Why can't I remember that sporting events are never a sure thing?!  I should have taken heed when  @Raahul_Kumar asked me ages ago about my extreme forecast.  Gaaah!  I made this forecast based on an analysis by 538 and my knowledge of the depth of the Norwegian team (my son has trained with several Olympians and coached Olympic nordic skiers).  Each day I've made a list of what gold medals the top countries might win; the list for Norway has always been the longest, until today.   I counted on Norway getting a gold or 2 out of the last Nordic skiing events--that hasn't happened--and now Germany has a good chance of pulling ahead because of their strong bobsled team.   Rats!

Time for me to make one final forecast for the evening, and then take a walk AWAY from these screens! I am going to assume that, with only 1.5km to go, and almost 3 minutes behind, Norway will NOT win the Cross Country Skiing (men's 50km). What gold medal opportunities remain? I list these roughly from most to least likely ... 
GERMANY in the Bobsleigh (4-man) 
NORWAY in the Cross-Country Skiing (women) 
GERMANY in the Ice Hockey (men)  And a mathematical possibility, but highly unlikely: 
GERMANY: Speed Skating (women's mass start). 
NORWAY: Speed Skating (men's mass start). At the end of today, the Speed Skating will be done, and almost certainly, Germany and Norway will still be tied on 13 gold each.   Tomorrow morning (Korean/Australian time), before Eastern US ticks over midnight, Germany will hit the front with a gold in the Bobsleigh (4-man).  Given, after 2 of 4 runs, the leading German team is 0.29 seconds ahead of the 2nd-placed Korean team, and another German team is only 0.06 seconds behind the Koreans, I put this as a 0.9 chance of a German win. After that, the Ice Hockey - though the OAR are heavy favourites, who knows what might happen?  OAR lost to Slovakia, after all. Give Germany a 0.3 here: OAR are roughly twice as likely to win as Germany. Finally, the Cross Country Skiing (women's 30km).  Betting houses seem to give a probability somewhere in the realm of 0.58 for Norway, 0.31 for Sweden, and 0.11 for Finland.  Round that to 0.6 for a Norway win. Now simplify.  There are 3 events remaining.  Relatively speaking, for each event either Germany will "win" (either by winning gold in the Bobsleigh or Ice Hockey, or by Norway NOT winning gold in the Skiing), or Germany will "lose" (either by Norway winning gold in the Skiing, or by Germany NOT winning gold in the Bobsleigh or Ice Hockey).  Overall, Germany winds up on top of the medal count if it "wins" 2 or 3 of these three events; Norway winds up on top or ties if Germany only "wins" 0 or 1 of these three events. Assuming the events are independent of each other, the possible outcomes are, in order of probability:
Germany WINS Bobsleigh; Norway WINS Skiing ; Germany LOSES Hockey --->  p=0.378
Germany WINS Bobsleigh; Norway LOSES Skiing ; Germany LOSES Hockey --->  p=0.252
Germany WINS Bobsleigh; Norway WINS Skiing ; Germany WINS Hockey --->  p=0.162
Germany WINS Bobsleigh; Norway LOSES Skiing ; Germany WINS Hockey --->  p=0.108
Germany LOSES Bobsleigh; Norway WINS Skiing ; Germany LOSES Hockey --->  p=0.042
Germany LOSES Bobsleigh; Norway LOSES Skiing ; Germany LOSES Hockey --->  p=0.028
Germany LOSES Bobsleigh; Norway WINS Skiing ; Germany WINS Hockey --->  p=0.018
Germany LOSES Bobsleigh; Norway LOSES Skiing ; Germany WINS Hockey --->  p=0.012 Overall, Germany "wins" 2 or 3 events, and thus tops the gold medal count 53.4% of the time.
Germany "wins" 0 or 1 event, thus Norway tops (or ties) the gold medal count 46.6% of the time. So yeah, I could have saved myself the last hour or two and just said, "It's a 50:50 coin toss!"

What gold medal opportunities remain? I list these roughly from most to least likely ...
GERMANY in the Bobsleigh (4-man)
NORWAY in the Cross-Country Skiing (men) 
GERMANY in the Ice Hockey (men) 
NORWAY in the Cross-Country Skiing (women)  And a mathematical possibility, but highly unlikely:
GERMANY: Speed Skating (women's mass start). 
NORWAY: Speed Skating (men's mass start).

Slalom snowboarding.  Interesting sport.  It seems as though two snowboarders race head to head, and then the one in the red lane goes through to the next round.  Not sure I see the sporting challenge in that.  (Red lane just won the last 20 races in a row.) So what gold medal opportunities remain? I list these roughly from most to least likely ... GERMANY in the Bobsleigh (4-man) = NORWAY in the Cross-Country Skiing (men) 
GERMANY in the Snowboarding (women's slalom)
GERMANY in the Ice Hockey (men)
NORWAY in the Cross-Country Skiing (women)
And a mathematical possibility, but highly unlikely: GERMANY: Speed Skating (women's mass start). 
NORWAY: Speed Skating (men's mass start).
Count is tied at 13 gold medals each for Norway and Germany. Looking at the few competitions left for which there are gold medal opportunities.

So close!  Only a handful of events to go, and still tied up at 13 gold a piece.  This makes it REALLY swingy from this point, as a single upset win (or loss) would be enough to make a difference.  Yes, upset wins/losses could have (and did) occur earlier in the games, but with plenty of events remaining, those random fluctuations would tend to cancel out. So what gold medal opportunities remain?  I list these roughly from most to least likely ... GERMANY in the Bobsleigh (4-man)
NORWAY in the Cross-Country Skiing (women)
GERMANY in the Ice Hockey (men) = NORWAY in the Cross-Country Skiing (men)
GERMANY in the Snowboarding (women's slalom) And a mathematical possibility, but highly unlikely: GERMANY: Snowboarding (men's slalom), Speed Skating (women's mass start).
NORWAY: Speed Skating (men's mass start). The big change to my estimation overnight is the German men's hockey team beating Canada.  In a 1-on-1 final with OAR, where the OAR team always have the chance of failing a drug test, anything might happen.
Did not see Germany with potential gold in hockey (still a long shot). I have continually discounted them (incorrectly on my part). Still think it will be Norway.

- tied for 13 golds but Norway much better at converting opportunities to medals
- also higher proportion of medals for Norway when compared to Germany's by about a third (35 total medals Norway vs 25 total for Germany) so if races are tight, say bobsleigh, then I give the edge to Norway to convert into something G,S,B: but higher edge to Norway to convert to one of the higher medals say gold or silver. - proportion of population (smaller number of choice among population to become elite athletes  for Norway than Germany by 1 to 18, which to me says Norway is doing something transformative (hopefully, legal) in terms of cutting edge elite sport recruiting or training... something which other countries will debrief and likely copy for next time once these games are over. Because of tie as of Friday feb 23 - not sure I want to go too far to 100% extreme...yet. I'd be 100% if Norway had one more gold than Germany at this point but not for a tie - there are too many minute little changes or upsets that could change things re Q

I have to cut short tonight's forecasts, as I am off to work.  Germany -v- Canada semifinal in the men's ice hockey - I presume Canada will win, but even if Germany fluke a win there, they would be up against OAR. Close but no cigar for Norway in both the Biathlon (men's relay) and Speed Skating (men's 1000m).  No gold for either Germany or Norway today. Projections: 
Norway = 14.4
Germany = 14.3 For Germany to hit the front in the gold count, they need to win the Bobsleigh (4-man) - which is a fair bet - and then either:
Have Norway win neither of the men's or women's Cross Country Skiing (where they are favourites); OR
Have Germany win another event - perhaps the Snowboarding (women's slalom)? More likely, Germany and Norway to win another gold each, and tie on 14 gold each, with Norway winning the tie. Chance of Germany winning is now, effectively, the chance of Norway winning _none_ of the men's X-Country, the women's X-Country, AND the Snowboarding (men's big air).

As of today, Norway and Germany are tied at 13 gold medals each. In terms of total, Norway has 35, followed by Germany with 25, Canada with 24. http://www.nbcolympics.com/medals
It's likely that the country with more overall medals will also win the most gold medals so I am increasing odds for Norway.
Tied now, with a few event left.  Tie looks like it would go to Norway.

Ken_Barns did all the heavy lifting on analysis here... Norway/Germany currently tied but slight edge to Norway. I’m likely too heavy on Norway but rooting for a nation of 5.3 million punching above their weight.

And that's it for the night.  Germany missing badly in the target shooting portion of the Biathlon (women's relay), and never being in the hunt for the gold, despite being the current world champions. Overall, a middling day for Germany, with the Biathlon loss offset by a surprise win in the Nordic Combined (men's relay) for 1 gold. Disappointing day for Norway, walking away with no gold, despite being favourites in one event, and strong medal prospects in another. Projections: 
Norway = 15.0 
Germany = 14.5 It's a thin day tomorrow, with me anticipating that neither nation will get a gold ... but Norway have a much better chance of winning a gold than Germany does. Pickings starting to get very thin from here.  Germany are as close to a certainty to get a gold in the Bobsleigh (4-man) as could be imagined, with any of three teams having a good chance to win.  But Norway are in with good prospects in the Biathlon (men's relay), Cross Country Skiing (men's 50km), and Cross Country Skiing (women's 30km).  Putting lesser prospects to one side, a Norwegian win in _any_ of those three are likely to result in a tied medal count, and thus a "tie-break win" for Norway. Good night all!

Four events to go where either Germany or Norway to get gold.
Bobsleigh 4: Germany almost certain favorite to get gold.
Biathlon relay men: Norway is favorite and Germany with chances however as we saw today biathlon might be lottery, so gold can go to someone else.
Women Cross country 30 km. Norway slight favorite. 
Man 50 km: Norway with slim chances to get gold.
Looks like man biathlon relay might be decisive.

UPSET!  Germany win the Nordic Combined (men's relay), an event that most (including me) had projected Norway to win.  That tilts things quite a bit: Germany +1 gold on what would have been expected, Norway -1, for a net +2 in Germany's favour.  Fortunately this is ameliorated a little by my forecast using "partial golds": I had Norway pencilled in as expecting 0.4 gold from this event, Germany as 0.3, so the net change is (Germany +0.7, Norway -0.4 = +1.1 in Germany's favour). Projections: 
Norway = 15.1 
Germany = 14.9 And now the Biathlon (women's relay): Germany as favourite.  A win here will put them ahead in the actual count by 1, and projected count by 0.5.
As of today, Feb. 21, Norway takes the lead with 13 gold medals, followed by Germany with 12, and Canada with 9.
Norway is currently leading in the number of gold medals and historically has the most gold metals for the winter Olympics.
Kudos to Ken Barnes’ breakdown. Just watched several events on TV and wow - Norway is killing it. (Admit bias via some Norwegian blood).
I just read what Ken Barns has on this one and add an additional point.  Without diving into each remaining sport and individual athlete, can't do much more work than he is already doing.

And that's it for the night. Norway stretches their lead a little, picking up 2 gold (I expected 0.9).  But Germany didn't do too badly either, picking up one gold (I expected 0.6). Projections: 
Norway = 15.8 
Germany = 14.2 Modal expectation for tomorrow? 1 gold each for Norway and Germany. Germany running out of opportunities to pull back 2 gold on Norway. Good night all!
Germany just got another gold in bobsleigh.
German athletes have been very strong in this season

Cleaning up my forecasts before the midnight GJO deadline, and before the day's event are too far progressed in Korea. Germany virtually eliminated from Speed Skating (women team) - was expected to get a medal.  Theoretically, all four teams in the semifinals could be disqualified ... but odds of that are very low. Germany in a better-than-I-expected position in the Bobsleigh (2-woman) with 2 out of 4 heats completed.  Germany and USA neck and neck in front, and a pack of 3 teams (Germany, US, Canada) about 1/3 of a second back.  Germany with a 0.45 of getting the gold here. Germany seeded 2nd in the women's, and 17th in the men's, Cross Country team sprint. Projections: 
Norway = 14.8 
Germany = 13.9 Modal expectation for today? 1 gold each for Norway and Germany.

Germans are clear favorites in two events (bobsleigh 4 and Nordic combination team event)
Norwegians  are clear favorites in just one (cross country Men's team sprint) Additionally Germans have high chances of winning biathlon women relay and women 2 bobsleigh where their pair is leading after day one. 
Norwegians have additional chances of winning golds in Men's biathlon relay and cross country 30 km event where are favorites and one more with cross country women sprint where their chances are high but lower than Sweden have.
Additionally there is slim chance that any of above medals that I assigned to Germany can be taken over by Norway while biathlon men's relay that I assigned to Norway is at risk to be taken by Germany.  Therefore I am far from announcing Norwegian victory and it still looks like close race for me.

Germany first, second, third in the Nordic Men's Large Hill, after Norway leading in the latter stages of the cross-country.   Germany really needed this, as they are running out of events where they are favourites.  If they had lost this, I would have dropped Germany to 2%.  If they had lost to Norway, game over! So pretty much back to where my forecast was 24hr ago, as the modal expectation for today was for Germany to get 1 gold and Norway to get none. Projections: 
Norway =14.9
Germany = 13.4 Modal expectation for tomorrow?  1 gold for Norway, none for Germany. *********************
I stand corrected - thanks @michalbod and his post here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/696775 German projection up to 13.8, and expectation for Germany is one gold today.

Bad choke by Germany in the final leg of the Biathlon (mixed relay), missing 6 targets, when only 2 had been missed in the previous 3 legs.  Gold for France.  Only saving grace is that Norway, who were 2nd-favourites, did not win gold either. Projections: 
Norway = 15.1
Germany = 12.8
as per discussion by @Ken_Barns and @Raahul_Kumar also ken was pretty darn close on the Fareed Zakaria new forecaster question

Norway is leading Germany 11 to 10, but also is projected to win more than Germany. https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-u-s-is-on-pace-for-a-lousy-olympics/

Norway now leads on both gold and total medals. Switching forecast.

Netherlands failure to medal in L and M 500m speed skate seems make odds too long.
Norway's gold in ski jump (Germany silver) reduces German opportunities for more gold.

2-19 at 8:45 am PST
Norway leads with 11 gold, 9 silver 
Germany 10 gold, 6 silver
Because Ken Barnes has an awesome brier score, and he has, 92 and 8, so I took his info, looked at a little research, and adjusted.

And that's it for the night.  Norwegian gold in the Men's Team Ski Jumping. Projections: 
Norway = 15.4 
Germany = 13.2

Photo finish in the 2-man bobsleigh.  Germany (and Canada) both win gold. Projections: 
Norway = 15.0 
Germany = 13.4

Norway GOLD in Men's Team Ski Jumping.   Projections:
Norway = 15.4
Germany = 12.8 ... and Germany looking shaky in the 2-man Bobsleigh too ... ************************
Scratch that ... there's another round to go in Ski Jumping.
World record skate putting Lorentzen (Norway) into the gold position in the 500m speed skating!   Projection for Norway up to 14.8, Germany at 13.0.

Ah bollocks.  Made an error in the data fields on my spread sheet.  Germany projected to get to 13.0; Norway to 14.0.  So Germany need at least one upset win over Norwegian favourites (possibilities include: men's team ski jump, Nordic men's relay, Biathlon men's relay) just to tie things up.  And a Norwegian upset over a German favourite (Biathlon mixed relay, Nordic men's large hill) would make it REALLY hard for Germany to catch up and overtake. Overall odds of 30 : 20 : 50, leaving Norway with a 70% chance of winning or tying.

Brain hurt now. Looking at the probability that Germany or Norway will win each event, I have Germany getting to 11.8 gold medals, and Norway getting to 12.7.  Given a tie will be broken in favour of Norway (by virtue of their silver medal haul), this a a fair margin in Norway's favour.   However, this is VERY swingy. For example, if Germany win the Men's Team Ski Jumping tonight, then they will jump to a projected haul of 12.6, and Norway drop to 12.3. So essentially 35 : 20 : 45 split (Germany : tie : Norway), giving Norway a total chance of 65% accounting for a tied gold medal count.

Ah how the odds have swung in the public eye towards Norway!  I'll have to do more of an event by event forecast as we head into the final week. Tonight, 3 medals up for grabs, with Germany and Norway tied at 9 gold each. BOBSLEIGH, 2-MAN
As sure as could be a gold for Germany.  In fact, a reasonable chance that Germany will take all 3 medals, with 3 pairs in the top 5 after 2 of 4 runs.  Norway not competing.  Finished by midnight Australian time (which, given I am recovering from an overnight shift, is OK by me). SPEED SKATING, MEN'S 500M
Norway and Germany each with 2 entrants.  Norway forecast to win a medal, Germany not.  2100 AEST. SKI JUMPING, MEN'S TEAM
Both Germany and Norway forecast to get medals, Norway favourites to win gold.  2230 AEST. All up, most likely outcome is Germany and Norway to get a single gold each tonight, but a little more likely that Germany will slip ahead (Germans more likely to win the Bobsleigh than Norway to win Ski Jumping).  And the Germans winning gold in the Ski Jumping would be a net +2 for Germany. On the other hand, I have to wind the German odds back a little as they lost the Women's biathlon and skeleton that they could have won.  Eased somewhat by the Norwegians failing to win the women's freestyle skiing.

Germany and Norway are tied for gold medals at the moment with 3 more than the next country. Of these Germany is the bigger country and so more likely to add to its total. Canada, while 4 medals behind is strong in some team sports that will be decided near the end of the games (ice hockey, curling) so is an outside chance for a late surge.
I'm a few days late to the question, so my bets are all-in to catch up. Which is why alphacast is better https://alphacast.cultivateforecasts.com
I am making this forecast because of the probabilities of how many times the countries are going to win another gold medal.

Norway gains an expected gold in X-Country, and a first gold, unexpected in my projections, in Freestyle Skiing. - if more Freestyle medals are won, Olympics may be over.
Germany lost a chance for a gold in Biathlon, a strength, leaving only  3 Biathlon golds to be awarded.
Netherlands lost a chance for gold in Speed Skating (L-500m). Current gold projections:
Norway: 13 1/4
Netherlands: 12 1/2
Germany: 12
Canada and Norway currently have 9 gold each with Norway having more medals total.
Oops, missed the "gold" part of the prediction.  NOR and GER are tied, so either could pull ahead. The others are all long shots.
Norway is pretty far in front.
The Attacking Vikings have more skiing events remaining than the Germans have biathlons.
Swapping Germany for Norway (I missed “gold” specific in question)
Good historical and projection data here.  https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-u-s-is-on-pace-for-a-lousy-olympics/

Based on current and projected performance https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-u-s-is-on-pace-for-a-lousy-olympics/

Projecting additional gold medals over yesterday's totals:
Netherlands: 6 1/2 for a total of 12 1/2 (wins with more silver) - still 10 speed skating + short track medals to be awarded.
Germany: 3 for total of 12 - Harvest of Luge & Biathlon gold (6) drawing to a close; hare might be caugh by the tortoise again...
Norway: 4 1/2 for a total of 13 1/4 - X-Country provided 4 golds so far, but only 3 events left.... Giving:
 Netherlands: 5 gold in speed skating, and 2 1/2 in short track speed skating.
Germany: 2 gold in Biathlon, 1 in ski jump, 1/2 in figure skating and 1 more in Nordic Combined.
Norway: 1 1/2 gold in Alpine, 3/4 in Biathlon, 1 1/2 in X-Country Ski, 1 in ski jump, 1 in Nordic Combined. Projections based on the medals already awarded in each class (for example the Netherlands has won 5 gold of the 6 speed skating events already completed).

Is there anything these guys _don't_ analyse to death???  https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-u-s-is-on-pace-for-a-lousy-olympics/ - see the final table. OR x 1.5 given an additional, independent data source (that is, a projection for results 18-25 Feb, based on historical performance in the remaining events) compared to what I used in my previous forecast. 4:1 (pre-test) x1.5 = 6:1 (post-test).  
6:1 = 86:14

Medal projections in the lead up to the Games seem to have evenly split between Norway and Germany winning the most gold medals.  There is a general consensus that Norway are more likely to win a few more medals overall. Actual gold medals to date (Germany 9, Norway 6) put Germany 1-2 gold ahead of where they would have been projected to be, and Norway 1-2 behind, based on projections for the specific events completed.  On that basis, Norway have fallen a little behind Germany. Looking at the "tail" of projected medals, both Germany and Norway could have been expected to be "gold heavy".  In actually won medals, Germany currently has 9 gold from 15 medals, and Norway has 6 gold from 19 medals.  In other words, Germany have so far converted medal chances into gold medals at roughly the expected rate; Norway has disproportionately (compared to expectations) won silver and bronze. Putting all this together, I would project the most likely outcome to be Germany 2 gold ahead of Norway at the end of the Games.  We are just under half-way through (from a medal point of view), and 2 gold is actually a fair margin to overcome given how close the eventual medal tallies (excluding host nations) usually are. Finally, German is currently at 9 gold, and a reasonable chance of winning 6 more (thanks, @michalbod!).  In the past 5 Winter Olympics, once the host is excluded, the "gold medal winning-est" nation received: 11, 10, 11, 12, and 11 gold medals.  The second-placed nation received: 10, 9, 9, 10, 9. For Norway to pass Germany from here, they would need to do VERY well, AND have Germany do poorly.  These eventualities are, in my opinion, only very weakly positively correlated.  I figure Germany's odds are 4 times better than Norway's (4:1 = 80:20) [[Among the others, the Netherlands and the USA seem to be slightly out-performing expectations; Canada performing at expectations.  Any of these three _might_ get to 10 gold, with the USA somewhat more likely than the other two but, unlike Norway, a MASSIVE collapse of the German team from this point onwards would be required to let any of those three slip in front of the German total.  Norway is, IMHO, the only realistic candidate who could pass Germany without a German collapse.]] REFERENCES:
_Many_ pages arising from a Google search for "projections for 2018 winter olympics medals".  In particular, I commend the obsessive fan page at: https://pyeongchang2018predictions.tumblr.com/
Also, putting a ceiling on the total Dutch haul of gold: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-dutch-own-a-single-sport-like-no-other-country-in-the-winter-olympics/

The outside view (statistics over the previous winter olympics starting 1992) would give 3 victories to Germany, 3 to Norway and 1 to Canada. The mean number of gold medals over the past seasons favors Germany but not by a significant margin. Germany has started strong and seems to be set to benefit most from the future medal competitions (according to another forecaster). Here is a link to a viewable spreadsheet with some info about medal distributions : https://www.dropbox.com/s/bj0ukvakvwvni0j/olympics.xlsx?dl=0

At the time of prediction Germany has 9, Norway 6. I do not see any other country as contender here. Germany have very high chances of  winning 6 more ( 3 biathlon, 2 Nordic combination, 1 Bobsleigh) that will give 15 total
For Norway 5 are almost sure ( 4 cross country, 1 biathlon) that will give 11 total. 
Than Norway have few more chances of gold (2 in cross country, 3 freestyle skiing, 1 Snowboard) but in those Norwegians are not clear favorites or not favorites at all.
Assuming both countries win their most probable gold medals Norwegians in order to tie would need to win at least 4 of their 6 chances which I believe is less ten 50% probable. Key competition which I did not include in above calculations is ski jumping where both countries are competing for 2 gold medals while can get none of them as well.
Results in 2014 https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/projects/sochi2014/results After 43 of 102 finals in 2018 Germany (9); Norway (6) and Canada (4) gold medals.

 USA	5	 (The record for most golds won in a single games was 14 by Canada in the 2010 Winter Olympics.) https://www.olympic.org/pyeongchang-2018/results/en/general/daily-medallists.htm

Germany has been tearing it up. Norway and the Netherlands are also strong contenders. The US is really good at very specific events, but is less likely to win things like Skeleton.
